newsitem.title: FRANCE: Paribas to sell Credit du Nord to Societe Generale.
newsitem.headline: Paribas to sell Credit du Nord to Societe Generale.

text.p: French financial holding company Paribas will start talks on a quick sale of its retail banking unit Credit du Nord to Societe Generale for 2.2 billion francs ($415 million), the two companies said Thursday.

The move was welcomed by analysts, who said it allowed Paribas to divest itself of retail banking and concentrate on its core businesses, and helped Societe Generale to meet a goal of boosting its domestic retail banking presence.
The two companies said in a joint statement that the transaction would take place in two stages.

"During the first phase, Societe Generale would take a controlling interest in Credit du Nord and would make a commitment to acquire the remainder of the company's equity within the next three years," they said.
Paribas has been trying since 1995 to get rid of its retail banking business to concentrate on international investment and merchant banking, and specialised financial services.
The joint statement said that for Societe Generale, the deal "offers a strategic fit with its objective of expanding retail banking operations in France."
Credit du Nord will benefit from the support of a major retail bank to accelerate its development and improve profitability, it said.
Banking analysts said the move was good for Paribas, which said it would make a 600 million franc ($113 million) capital gain from the sale, but perhaps a less obvious positive for the buyer.
The stock market cheered the deal, sending shares in Paribas and Societe General 4.02 percent and 2.22 percent higher, respectively, at the close.
